div.p: 1. VI:45. Just as I was rising, a firing of Cannon and of Musketry, and the ringing of Bells announced the celebration of a Holiday; it being the anniversary of the deliverance of Bruxelles; that is of the entrance of the allies— The firing, and the Bell-ringing continued the whole day through, at intervals, and in the Evening there was an illumination of the City— Mr Bauwens called upon me to say that the Tribunal of appeal would not sit this day for business on account of the Holiday; so that I must give up entirely the idea of seeing it— At 11 O’Clock I went to the Old Palace, and saw successively the Museum, the Public Library and Cabinet of Natural History— The Museum contains a large and valuable collection of Pictures, by the Principal Masters of the Italian, Flemish and Dutch Schools, with not more than four or five Pictures by French Painters— They are in seventeen Saloons or Chambers— Divided into three sets of Seven, five and five. These last are all antient Pictures, painted before the invention of oil-colours— The greatest and most curious collection of the kind that I have seen— The Museum was formed in 1801. and the great proportion of the best pictures was sent to it as presents from the French Government at Paris. Most of them are large Church Pieces, and there is of course too much uniformity in the subjects. There are none of the small, gay and humorous pieces of the Dutch painters of vulgar life— There are also several pieces of Sculpture and Basso Relievos; and several prize pictures crowned by the Academy the last three years— The antient Pictures, painted before the time of John Van Eyck of Bruges, the inventor of Paintings in Oil are very numerous, and in an excellent state of preservation— I was nearly three hours in going through all the Halls, although they were cold and uncomfortable, so that my guide at one time left me and went away for an hour— The Library is also a numerous and valuable collection of Old Books, but contains very few published within the last thirty years. The librarian not being there I could not obtain access to the Manuscripts. The Cabinet of Natural History serves for the Lectures of a Professor attached to the Institution— It contains the usual Apparatus for Electrical, chemical and Galvanic Experiments—Minerals, Marbles, Crocodiles, Birds of Paradise and Rattlesnakes— The Electrical Machine was different from any that I had heretofore seen, and was said to be an improvement upon those heretofore used— There were two large circular wooden vessel standing on their edges, with concave surfaces lined with tin, and a small tin pipe in the Centre of one of them, placed opposite to each other, each concave side towards the other; which the man who attended me said were acoustic machines, to explain the theory of the transmission of sounds— The softest whisper at one of them could be distinctly heard by listening at the other, of which he gave me the proof— And he told me that it disclosed the secret of the invisible Lady, as no doubt it does— I took one of the Catalogues of the Pictures in the Museum which is very indifferently composed; and left the house just before three O’Clock— Went to a Bookseller’s shop, and purchased a french Post Book of the present year for Mr Smith, and a new French work by Baron Boyer upon Surgery; to send to Mr Bossuyt. Mr Ranwet came with the Compliments of Mr Vlieshouwer, and invited me to a great Ball this Evening at the Vauxhall, where the hereditary Prince of Orange was to attend, and where all the principal Noblesse of the City would be. Mr Vlieshouwer himself he said was not of the Society; but an intimate friend of his, General Chateler had promised to introduce me, if I should incline to go— I desired Mr Ranwet to give my thanks to Mr Vlieshouwer for his attention, but as I intended to leave the City at five O’Clock to-morrow Morning, I should want all this Evening to prepare for my departure— A Ball was a species of amusement in which I could take no other share than as a Spectator, and having only a few days to stay here when I came I had neglected to obtain a presentation to the hereditary Prince of Orange, and could not conveniently appear in a private Society where he would be present.— I dined at the Table d’Hote and was the whole Evening in my chamber, preparing to start at five to-morrow Morning— Mr Bauwens came and took leave of me, and mentioned that he should return this Night to Ghent— I sent to his lodgings the packets I had made up for Mr Smith and Mr Bossuyt, with Letters for them both— This afternoon I received a letter from my wife, of 6. January, forwarded to me by Messrs: Meulemeester, from Ghent.

2. III.30. Cambray. The Horses had been ordered for me at five O’Clock this Morning; and I was in waiting for them at that time— It was however more than half past five before they came, and I left the Hotel de Flandre
just before six, as the day began to dawn. My principal motive for departing so early was to reach Valenciennes before six in the Evening, when the gates of the City are shut, and being now a frontier town they are not opened for travellers nor until six in the Morning— The distance from Bruxelles is eleven Posts and a quarter, and the allowance to be made is of about an hour for each Post; stopping only to change horses. From Bruxelles to Mons seven Posts I had only one Postilion, for the four horses, but from Mons, according to the French Ordinances I had two On the other hand there were from two to two and a half franks at each Stage charged for Turnpikes or Barrieres, until the French frontier, but which there ceased. I was at Mons between 12. and 1. O’Clock and there met at the Post-House a Gentleman belonging to Ghent, who recognized and spoke to me, though I did not recollect having seen him there— I arrived at Valenciennes at 5 O’Clock just before dark, and then determined to proceed another Stage to Bouchain. There I found the Post-house was without the walls of the City, and that there was no house to lodge at— I was obliged therefore to proceed another Stage of two Posts to Cambray— There I found the Gates were shut, but they were opened to let us into the City— I stopp’d for the Night at the Hotel de Hollande, opposite the Post-Office, where I alighted, at half-past eight in the Evening— I had travelled 15 1/2 Posts in 15 Hours—never stopping but to change horses. At Mons I was asked for my Passport— At Quievrain the Netherland frontier again, and enquiry was made if I had any thing subject to export duties— At Valenciennes, the enquiry was whether I had any thing contrary to the king’s ordinances, but no examination of my baggage was any where attempted or required. The Roads were as bad as the Season could make them, and at the side of the pavement was a deep mire— The whole road is paved— The ground was every where bare, excepting here and there a small spot where there was a remnant of Snow— The farmers in some places were ploughing up the ground— The aspect of the Country had all the deadness and dreariness of the Season excepting the wheat-fields where the grain had already shot up enough to cover them with verdure— The Country is generally level, and in the flourishing seasons one of the most fertile regions of the Earth— At the Stages from Valenciennes and Bouchain I had to pay four and a half franks for what the Postilions call le decouché— That is for the lodging of the Postilions and horses, who by the shutting of the gates are prevented from returning home— From Bruxelles I had to pay for half a Post, and from Mons and Valenciennes a quarter of a Post in addition to the distance— An allowance granted at most of the principal where the Postilions and horses are subject to longer detention than at the ordinary Post-houses.— I had taken two small rolls of bread into the Carriage, and had neither ate nor drank any thing else since leaving Bruxelles. I took a very light Supper, and ordered my horses at half past five to-morrow morning, the gates of the City being opened precisely at six.

3. IV:30. Gournay sur Aronde. I left the Hotel de Hollande just at six of the Morning, and the City of Cambray at the opening of the Gates. After travelling five Posts I reached Peronne, at half-past ten O’Clock, and was detained there upwards of an hour, one of the iron Cramps, that keep the spring over the right fore wheel of the Carriage, and employed the blacksmith an hour to repair it. Two Stages further a blacksmith came and examined the Carriage and told me that my fore-right wheel was not solid— I thought he only wanted a job, and told him so— I proceeded another Stage to Roye, and there as the Carriage stopp’d at the Post-house a blacksmith came up, and told me that my left fore-wheel was so loose that I certainly should not get along a quarter of a Post further before it would break down— That it creaked so loud it could be heard quite across the Street— Though I could not perceive that there was so immediate a danger of the wheels this coincidence between two persons who could not have had any concert together gave me some alarm, and I stopped three quarters of an hour at Roye to have the fellies of the fore wheels bound with ropes; something to the disappointment of the blacksmith who had given me the notice, and who had calculated upon a much longer job of work for himself— I then proceeded three stages further to Gournay-sur-Aronde, where I resolved to stop for the Night, though it was only half past six in the Evening, and I had travelled only twelve Posts this day. With my precarious wheels I thought it better to travel before daylight in the morning rather than after dark in the Evening. I lodged at the Hotel du Grand Cerf, and ordered the horses to be ready at 4 O’Clock to-morrow Morning.

4. III:30. Paris. At a quarter past four in the Morning I took my departure from Gournay-sur-Aronde, and reached Pont Sainte Maxence, the second Stage, just after day-light.— On starting from this Stage, I found a Bridge over the river Oise, which had been blown up last Winter to stop the passage of the Cossacks, and which they are now rebuilding. This was the first and only trace of injury to the Country from the late War, that I perceived on the road. The Bridge is already sufficiently restored for foot-passengers but not for Carriages— I crossed it myself and waited on the South side of it for my Carriage which went over in a ferry boat, about two hundred yards below. I met on the Paris side of the Bridge a Miller, who told me that the Bridge had been blown up to stop the Cossacks— 800 pounds of powder he said had been employed for the purpose. I heard the name of the Cosacks mentioned only one other time upon the road; and that was by a Postilion whose horse was restive and threw him off. He called the horse Sacré Cosaque in Revenge— As I approached Paris the drivers became more alert in their movements— My Carriage was not stop’d at-all for the examination of baggage at the entrance of the City, and at one O’Clock in the afternoon I alighted at the Hotel du Nord Rue de Richelieu, a house which had been recommended to me by Mr Gallatin. I took the only vacant Apartments in the house; which are two small chambers in the second Story, upon the Street. There is a Restaurateur or Cook in the house. I engaged a Valet de Place named Louis, and after having dressed and dined took a Hackney Coach and called at Mr Crawford’s— He and Mr Clay were just gone out to Madame Catalani’s Concert at the Opera house— I then went to the Hotel de l’Empire Rue d’Artois, to see Mr Bayard, and to the Hotel d’Avranches in the same Street to see Mr Russell, but they were both out; upon which I returned to my lodgings.
Itinerary of my Journey from Bruxelles to Paris.

The regular payment is 1 1/2 frank by the Post for each horse— The Ordinance allows only 75 Centimes per Post for each Postilion, but the usage is to give them 1 1/2 frank, the same as for a horse, and they are never satisfied with that. It is indeed an universal principle with them to ask for more, whatever you give them. I usually gave them half a frank for the two. The number of beggars that crowd round your Carriage at every Post-house is from 10 to 20. and most of them objects of great wretchedness— The Blacksmith appears with equal regularity in search of his job; examines very closely the Carriage and gives notice of all necessary repairs. The aspect of the Cities and of the Country is precisely what it was 30 years ago.

5. VI. I scarcely slept a moment the whole Night. My chambers front upon the street, which is one of the greatest thoroughfares in Paris; and the present is a time of more than ordinary noise and bustle, these being the last days of the Carnaval— There was no cessation the whole Night through, of the rolling of Carriages in the Street— I employed the morning, chiefly in writing to my wife. Mr Crawford, Mr Clay, Mr Bayard and Mr Todd paid me visits this morning, and Mr Crawford and Mr Todd, delivered me several letters, that have been some time here waiting for me. I dined at Mr Crawford’s at half past five O’Clock; with a company of about twenty-five persons— Among them were General Dumas a Mr La Grange a lawyer— Mr Bayard and Coll: Milligan who has arrived here lately from England.— Mr Jackson, a brother of General Jackson of Georgia with whom I sat in the Senate of the U.S. is Mr Crawford’s Secretary. One of General John Mason’s sons of Georgetwon is also with him as private Secretary. It was near ten in the Evening when I returned from Mr Crawford’s to my lodgings.

6. VI:15. Mr Crawford had mentioned to me yesterday that there would be a cercle diplomatique at Court to-morrow, and asked me if I chose to be presented to the king and royal family— I had answered that I would, and called this morning upon Mr Crawford to ascertain the time when it would be necessary to go— He desired me to call on him at Noon. I also took and left with him the three Millions of dollars Certificates of Stock of the Loan of 1814. standing in the names of Messrs: W. and J. Willink of Amsterdam, which Mr Boyd brought from America, and left with me— I also called at Mr Clay’s chamber but he was not at home— I paid no other visits this day, but in the Evening went to the Italian Opera at the Odeon where I saw La Griselda, with the Music of Paer— This is the least frequented of all the Theatres of Paris— The house was however very tolerably filled. They perform there alternately in Italian and in French.

7. VI:30. At half-past eleven O’Clock I called at Mr Crawford’s house, where Mr Russell, Mr Clay, Mr Jackson, Coll: Milligan and Mr Todd soon after assembled, and we all proceeded together just at twelve to the Thuileries. Most of these Gentlemen had already been presented a fortnight ago, and now went again— Mr Bayard did not now attend.— We waited only a few minutes in the introductory hall—where I found an old acquaintance of mine; the Chevalier Brito, Chargé d’Affaires from Portugal; whom I had known at the Hague— I was introduced to General Waltersdorf the Danish Minister, who told me he had been in America, and had known my father there— And I also was recognized by Genl: Fagel whom I had known at Berlin; and who is now the Dutch Minister here— I was introduced to Mr Dargainaratz the king’s Secretary à la conduite des Ambassadeurs, and to Mr Lalive, introducteur des Ambassadeurs— We were presented first to the king, and then successively to the Duchess and Duke d’Angouleme, and then to Monsieur-Comte d’Artois and lastly to the Duke de Berri— We were presented by Mr Crawford, as according to the etiquette of this Court, Strangers are presented by the Ministers of their respective Countries— The king, Princes, and Princess seldom
speak to any person presented to them— The king however asked me, if I “was any related to the celebrated Mr Adams”— Mr Crawford answered for me that I was son to the former President of the United States— The Princes also spoke to me each a few words; all in English, excepting the Duke d’Angouleme who spoke in French.— The Duchess d’Angouleme did not speak to any of the persons presented— The Ceremonies were all over in the course of an hour— Lord Fitz-Roy Somerset had been previously presented at a private Audience, and delivered his Credentials as British Minister Plenipotentiary since the departure of the Duke of Wellington the Ambassador— He presented several English Gentlemen at the Circle— Count Nicholas Pahlen was presented by Mr Lalive; there being only a Russian Chargé d’Affaires, at this Court; who according to the etiquette does not present. I returned home about two O’Clock; changed my dress and went to pay visits to Madame de Stael and to Count Marbois— Madame de Stael was still in bed; but sent by her son requesting me to come and see her to-morrow Evening; and to dine with her next week on Wednesday— I was received by Count Marbois whom I had not seen since the year 1785. and with whom I had a long and interesting political Conversation.— Dined at home and went in the Evening to the Opera-Comique— Saw Les deux Jaloux, Jean de Paris, and l’Habit de Grammont. The house was excessively crowded.

8 VI:30. I changed this Morning my Apartments from N 13. on the second Story, and fronting upon the Street to N. 2. on the first floor fronting upon the yard— My principal reason for changing was that the chambers I first took constantly smoke. I had a visit from Mr R. Boyd, a half brother of George Boyd’s— And I spent almost the whole day in paying visits, myself— To Mr Hottinguer, to whom I delivered the Letter of Introduction and of Credit from Messrs: Willink and Van Staphorst of Amsterdam. To Mr Russell, whom I found at his lodgings at-the Hotel d’Avranches, Rue d’Artois— To Messrs: Bayard, Todd, J. Russell, and Erving, and to the Chevalier Brito, none of whom I found at home— I took a walk upon the Boulevards, the first time I have found for a walk since I came into Paris— Dined at home alone; and in the Evening I went and paid visits to Mr Laval, whom the present king of France has made a Count, and afterwards to Madame de Stael, where I found a company of about twenty persons none of whom I knew— She introduced me to Mr Suard, an old Gentleman, of some distinction, as a Man of Letters, with whom, and an Englishman whose name I did not ascertain, I had some conversation upon general topics— It was between ten and eleven in the Evening, when I returned to my lodgings.

9: VI:30. A Mr Baron de Provisi had written a letter to me on Monday, requesting to see me, to obtain information concerning grants of lands in America, where he expressed a desire of forming a settlement— I appointed this day at Noon to receive him at my lodgings, and he came at the time— I gave him such information as I possessed. I paid visits to Mr Boyd, the Uncle, whom I found at home, and to Messrs: Barnet the American Consul, Appleton and Maclure; neither of whom was at his lodgings— I also called and spent an hour with Mr Crawford— He came at half past five and took me up, and we went and dined with Count Marbois— There was a Company of about 20 persons, at dinner, and a number more came in afterwards— The Count’s son in Law, the Duke de Plaisance, the Duke de Choiseul and several Ladies were of the party; but the Count’s Daughter the Duchess de Plaisance was not there. A Mr Gaussin sat next to me at table, and told me he had been Chargé d’Affaires of France at Berlin, when Mr Lee lost his papers. He mentioned several circumstances relating to that transaction, some of which I had not heard of before— In the Evening I went with Mr Crawford to the Theatre François, and saw Polyeucte, with a new farce called Les deux Voisines. Talma and Mlle: Duchesnois performed in the Tragedy, but they were in the third Act when we arrived, and we were at a great distance from the Stage; so that I could not distinguish them. The farce was very bad.

10. VII:30. My time is almost consumed in paying and receiving visits, and I rise almost every morning after day-light— This morning I was later than I have been I believe, in the whole course of the winter— I was however unwell with a Cold, Cough, and a little fever. Count Marbois, who is the first President of the Chambre des Comptes, had promised to procure seats for Mr Crawford, Mr Clay, and me, at the Tribunal de premiere instance, a neighbouring Court to that where he presides, and where the trial is pending between the Count and the Duchess de Saint Leu, the former king and Queen of Holland, upon the question whether she should be compelled to send to him their eldest Son, whom the present king of France has created Duke of St: Leu. We were to meet at Count Marbois’s Cabinet at a quarter before 9 this morning, which we did— He requested a Gentleman to accompany us, with his grand daughter, a girl, of eight or nine, to the Tribunal, where we obtained seats. The Court opened at ten— There was a President, with eight associate judges. The chamber where the Court sits is very small— I think not thirty feet square— And the crowd of Spectators so great, that one of the doors of the Hall was broken down, and there was danger that some fatal accident would have happened— The cause had already been
argued on both sides, and this day had been assigned for Mr Tripier the Council for the father, Louis Buonaparte to reply, to the defence, and for Mr Bonnet the Advocate for the Duchess to make his concluding observations on the reply. It is a Cause upon which in the United States no Court could have jurisdiction— There are very few cases in which it would occur here. The basis of Tripier’s Argument was the paternal authority; that of his opponent’s was the interest of the child— There was scarcely any recurrence to first principles; no exposition of the Laws of France or of other Nations upon the subject— These had apparently formed the materials of the preceding argument— The opinions of Chancellor d’Aguesseau; of Mr Joly de Fleury, and of a Procureur General at a Court of Cessation had been cited by Bonnet, and Tripier commented upon them— He spoke about an hour and a half— Bonnet closed in about half an hour— The Attorney General, who in the French Courts is a sort of mediator between the parties, an Amicus Curiae, like the Judge-Advocate of a Court-Martial, is to sum up the cause on both sides next Friday; to which time the cause was for that purpose adjourned. It appeared by the admission of the Council on both sides, that in the case of a legalized Separation of the parties from bed and board, the Court would have a discretionary power to commit the child either to the father or mother, as they should think its own interest would dictate— The question was whether such a Separation existed— A Separation in point of fact has existed for seven years— The family Statutes had regulated how such Separations were to be legalized in the Imperial family.— And that was to be by the mere authorisation of the Emperor, without judicial process or formality— Of this authorization in the present case the evidence was as loose, and imperfect, as the principle was arbitrary and inconsiderate— It was merely a letter from the Grand Marshal of the Palace Duroc to the Mother, after the abdication by Louis of the throne of Holland, declaring that by the Emperor’s authority he had ordered possession to be taken in her name, of the Hotel belonging to her husband in Paris, and had assigned a million of franks for her, 500000 for the Grand Duke of Berg, (the Son in question) and 250000 franks for the youngest son. And this is the proof upon which the Court is called to pronounce the dissolution of the father’s rights and his authority over his child. The lawyers were both fluent and eloquent Speakers; but both have bad voices, and Tripier speaks thick, with an incapacity of uttering either the letters r or s. After the adjournment of the Court I paid a visit to Mr Le Ray de Chaumont, and upon my return home received visits from Mr de Castries, who had come in last Evening, while we were at Count Marbois—he is going immediately to Rouen, where his father the Duke de Castries has the military command. I had also visits from the Chevalier Brito, from Mr Speyer, and Mr Jos. Russell, and from Mr Todd— I dined and spent the Evening at Mr Hottinguer’s where I met Messrs: Crawford, Bayard, Clay and Russell, a Mr Livio from St: Petersburg and several Strangers— There was a large company in the Evening— Ladies and Gentlemen— Among whom the Russian General Driessen, and Mr and Mrs Boyd— There was a dance of the young gentlemen and Ladies, one of the Ladies playing the tunes upon the Piano— I played whist with Messrs: Crawford, Clay and Russell; and returned about Midnight to my lodgings.— Mr Thompson of Baltimore, and an Englishman lately from Charleston were of the dinner.

11. VII:15. I received yesterday a Letter from Messrs: Meulemeester of Ghent, enclosing two Letters of Introduction, to Messrs: Carette et Minguet and to Mr Guerin Dufoncin, Merchants— I went this Morning to deliver these Letters, and neither of the Gentlemen being at home I left them, with Cards— I also paid visits to the Duke de la Vauguyon, to Count Beurnonville, to Count Destutt de Tracy, and his son Victor de Tracy, to Mr Pichon and to Mr Speyer— Mr Pichon was the only person whom I found, and I had an hour’s Conversation with him, and with Madame Pichon.— Count de Tracy and his Son, were paying me a visit, precisely at the time when I was visiting them. The Duke de La Vauguyon sent me word that he could not receive me, as the surgeon was dressing his leg, and he had been very ill; but that he would call upon me at my lodgings— Mr Todd paid me a visit with Mr Warden, formerly our Consul General here, and on returning home I found several other Cards of visitors— I took a walk before dinner in the Garden of the Palais Royal, which I found very little altered from what I had left it in 1785— In the Evening I went first to the Theatre des Varietés where it was impossible to obtain a ticket; and then I went to the theatre de la gaieté, where I saw Les Ruines, ou Giafar de Barmécide, and the Dog of Montargis—performed not better than I had seen it at Ghent— I met here a young American named Cunningham who recognized me. It was about 11 when I came home.

12. VII. The tendency to dissipation at Paris seems to be irresistible— There is a moral incapacity for industry and application; a mollesse against which I am as ill-guarded as I was at the age of twenty— I received on Friday a Letter from Mr Smith, requesting me to look out for lodgings for him, and Mr Todd promised me yesterday, to call upon me this day at noon, and go out with me for the purpose. He came accordingly and we walked— Among the houses to which I went was the Hotel de Valois, the same house where I lodged with my father in 1778. April the first time I ever was at Paris— It was then a magnificent and elegantly furnished Hotel— It is now altogether in decay, and scarcely furnished at all— Yet the price of the Apartments is as high as at the best Hotels— We also went to the Hotel d’Orleans, Rue des Petits-Augustins, and to one or two others, but I concluded to take lodgings for Mr Smith for one week at the house where I am the
Hotel du Nord. I went with Todd, rather by accident than design into the Salon d’Exposition and the National Museum, where, intending to spend half an hour, we passed three whole ones, and finally were obliged to withdraw at four O’Clock when the doors were to be closed. The multitude of objects was such as left my mind in a state of confusion— The Apollo; the Laocoon, the Venus de Medicis, with a great number of other antique Statues—the transfiguration of Raphael, the Descent from the Cross by Rubens, and all the master-pieces of painting here collected, contrasted with the glare of colouring, and unnatural attitudes of the pictures at the exposition, took from me all faculty of meditation and almost of discrimination— It was five O’Clock when I came home; and I spent the Evening in my chamber; writing; and endeavouring to retrieve the arrears of this Journal, which had already run up to nine or ten days.

13. V:30. When I pass the Evening quietly at home, I can rise early the next morning; of which this day was an example— I had agreed with the Chevalier Brito, to meet him at a quarter before 3 O’Clock P.M. at the Library of the National Institute, to attend the meeting of the first Class which is held every Monday at that hour— Mr Pichon and Mr Hubbard, formerly a partner in the house of Van Staphorst at Amsterdam came in successively after two O’Clock, and detained me at home until past 3— I then went first to the Bibliotheque du Roi, where I had by mistake supposed Mr Brito had appointed to meet me— It was already shut, upon which I went to the Institute, and found the Library; but it was more than half past three— Brito was not there— The meeting had begun at three, and the door-keeper told me that I could not enter without a ticket, or being introduced by a member. I then looked over the Salon d’exposition of designs in Architectures and afterwards returned home, walking round, by the Pont Royal, and the Garden of the Thuileries. I find the alterations in them less than I had expected— After dining at home, I went to the Theatre of the Odeon, and saw Il Matrimonio Secreto, the Master-piece of Cimarosa; the most enchanting Music that I ever heard— The house was not full. I came home before eleven.

14. VII:15. Mr Erving who called and sat with me an hour the day before yesterday told me that Mr Crawford was unwell; confined to his bed— I met yesterday Mr Bayard in the garden of the Thuileries— He had seen Mr Crawford in the morning, and found him much better— I went to see him this morning, and spent an hour with him. He is yet confined to his chamber, with symptoms of a catarrhal fever; but he is recovering— Mr Clay was not at home— I paid visits to Counts Theodore and Nicholas Pahlen, to Coll: Milligan, and Messrs. Swetchkoff, Todd, Hubbard, Petry, Sheafe, and Warden; of whom I found only Theodore Pahlen and Mr Warden at home.— Mr Warden told me he was engaged upon a work relative to the United States, and made some enquiries for information concerning them— I dined with Messrs: Carette and Minguet, for whom Mr Meulemeester has sent me a letter— Messrs: Bayard, Clay, and Todd were there, with a company of 15 or 16 French Ladies and Gentlemen, with none of whom I had any acquaintance— It is not the custom of the place to introduce Strangers to one another. I came home about 9 in the Evening.

15. V:30— The arrears of this journal are again retrieved— Mr Smith called upon me this morning, having arrived with his family in the City, yesterday at Noon— They did not come through St. Denis, and he accordingly did not receive the Letter I had written to inform him that I had taken lodgings for him at this Hotel— They went to the Hôtel de l’Europe, Rue St. Honoré, near the Palais Royal— I gave immediate notice to my landlady, Madame Coran, that the chambers which I had engaged would not be wanted, and it proved to be no disappointment to her, as she had an immediate opportunity of letting them to other persons— I had morning visits from Mr Purviance, and from Mr Victor de Tracy— I had received on Monday a note from General La Fayette, mentioning that he would come to the City this day, and remained at home expecting him all the morning, until Mr de Tracy informed me that he would be at the dinner at Madame de Stael’s. I went to see Mrs Smith at the Hotel de L’Europe— On returning to my lodgings I waited until half past five, for Mr Clay, who was to have called to take me up— I then took a Carriage, and on arriving at Madame de Stael’s found Mr Clay there— He had called for me after I left my lodgings— General La Fayette, Mr Victor de Tracy, and Mr Le Ray de Chaumont dined there, with the Duke de Broglie, who is to marry Madame de Staél’s daughter, several other Gentlemen, and one Lady— Mr Benjamin Constant was of the party. There were seventeen persons at the table. The Conversation was not very interesting. Some discussion between the Lady & Mr Constant, who appeared to consider it as a principle to contradict her— At one time there were symptoms of a Conversations arising upon a subject of political economy, upon which she said, j’interdis tout discours sur l’economie politique— Ah! je crains l’economie politique comme le feu— Immediately after dinner she left us, saying, je vous laisse mon fils, qui est très aimable, and went to the Theatre François, to see the Tragedy of Esther— She invited me to come and see her again, and said she was at home almost every evening. She also apologized for being obliged to leave her company so soon, pour aller au Spectacle. I went myself with Mr Le Ray de Chaumont to the Odeon, and saw le Nozze de Fïgaro, with the Music of Mozart— They were about the middle of the second Act, when we went in— The music is charming, but not equal to that of the Matrimonio Secreto.

16. VI:45. I received this morning an answer from my wife to my letter of 27. December, inviting her to come and meet me here— She will come as soon as possible, and will I hope be here in the course of a Month.— Mr Smith came at twelve O’Clock; soon afterwards Mr Dorr called upon me, and General La Fayette, who finding company with me promised to come and breakfast with me to-morrow Morning— I called with Mr Smith upon Mr Crawford, whom we found still very unwell; and afterwards upon Mr Boyd, who was not at home— I took a walk of an hour and a half before dinner— After dinner I paid a visit to Count Marbois, at whose house I found some company; Ladies and Gentlemen; all unknown to me.— He introduced me to his daughter the Duchess de Plaisance, who told me she was born in Philadelphia, but had been taken from it when six months old and from America at four years and a half— She had forgotten the English language, and afterwards learnt it here. I asked the Count to procure admission for me again at the Tribunal de premiere instance, when the St. Leu cause should again be taken up which he promised he would; and he introduced me to two Gentlemen of the Bar, one of whom promised also to procure for me tickets for the Session of the Cour d’Assise at a jury trial. I asked him how the trial by jury was found to succeed here; he said not well— That the Jurors were dissatisfied with their functions and always leaned too strongly in favour of the accused— I went and passed an hour with Mrs Smith; with whom I found Mr R. Boyd; and then went to the Ball at Count Laval’s— The first person I met there was Count Lauriston, who introduced me to his Lady—Countess Schuvaloff, General Driessen, the Counts Pahlen, Mr Swetchkoff, and Mr Boutiagin the Russian Chargé d’Affaires were there, with several other Russians and a numerous company of French, scarcely any of whom were known to me— The Marquis de Torcy, General Waltersdorff, Madame de Stael, and her son and daughter were among them— Madame de Laval asked me to come to-morrow at one O’Clock, and see some pictures which are to be brought to her to look at, and which are for sale— I came home just before two O’Clock in the Morning.

17. VII:30. General La Fayette came and breakfasted with me, and sat with me until Noon— At one I went to Count Laval’s, and found Madame La Comtesse examining the pictures which were offered to her for sale— There was a small picture damaged decayed, and repaired, but attributed to Julio Romano—a Sketch painted on copper of Christ healing the sick; and two little paintings on wood, which they pretended were found at Pompeii—their price for the whole was 16000 franks, for the Julio Romano alone 8000— A five frank piece would have been more than the worth of the whole. Madame de Laval was not the dupe of this imposition— She dismissed the man and his pictures, though she did not think quite so meanly of them as I did— I then paid visits to General Fagel, Chevalier de Brito, Mr Purviance, to the Hotel de l’Empire, for Mr Thompson, Mr. Bayard, and Mr Todd, to Mr Russell at the Hotel d’Avranches; to Count Lauriston, and to Mr Dorr— I found only Mr Purviance and Mr Dorr at home— Mr Sheafe and Mr Russell came in at Mr Dorr’s while I was there. I returned home to dinner; and in the Evening, after spending an hour with Mr and Mrs Smith’s I went to Mr Hottinguer’s, where I met a large company of Ladies and Gentlemen, most of whom were unknown to me— Count Lauriston and his Lady were there—Mr Boyd and his family—Mr and Mrs Hubbard, the latter of whom did not remember me. I played whist, with Mr Maillardez, formerly a Minister here from the Swiss Confederation, and two other Gentlemen— I came home just before twelve at Night.

18. VII:30. I received this day a Letter from my wife, dated the 1st. of this Month which must be a mistake— After going to the Bank of France I spent an hour and a half at the Museum; in one Hall, called la Salle des Fleuves, or the Hall of the Rivers; because among the Monuments of Antient Sculpture which it contains are two enormous River Gods, the Nile and the Tyber. The only expositions in this Hall are Statues, Busts, and other samples of antique Sculpture— Among them are the Venus of the Capitol, the Hermaphrodite and the Centaur— At three O’Clock I called upon Mr Smith and went with him to the Count Destutt de Tracy’s, whom we saw; as also his Lady, his son, the Major, and General La Fayette— I dined at home, and in the Evening went to the Theatre of the Odeon, where I saw Il Re Theodore, with the Musick of Paësiello— The house was thin, and this Theatre is soon to be closed.

19. VII:15. I had morning visits from Mr Storrow, and Mr Barnet. Mr Storrow has just arrived from England. He intends to embark at Havre, in ten days or a fortnight for America, and offered to take Letters or dispatches for me. Mr Barnet is the Consul for Havre, and acts at present, provisionally as Consul General. He told me he had two sons at Pestalozzi’s school in Switzerland, and I made some enquiries of him concerning a school, where I might place either of my Sons— I wrote to my wife and enclosed my letter to Messrs. Schwenk and Koch at Königsberg, at two O’Clock I walked out and spent two Hours at the Museum— Altogether in the Halls of Antient Sculpture and without completing the particular examination of them— The Apollo, the Venus and the Laocoon absorb the Consideration of every thing else— The eye of the
enquirer begins and ends with them— The Venus however has disappointed me. It has suffered much damage, and one of the arms, and both the hands are restored— The Modern Sculpture of the exhibition is in the same Halls with the Antiques, and offer subjects for comparison to estimate the relative perfection of the Art at the present day.— I am still not prepared for committing to paper my remarks. At 4 O’Clock the doors are closed, and I had just entered the Hall of the Apollo, when the company received notice to retire. I went beyond the river and took a walk in the Luxemburg Gardens. Dined at home and in the Evening went to the Theatre Francois, where I saw l’Orphelin de la Chine, and les deux Voisines again. La Fon performed Gengis Kan; and Mlle. Georges Idamé— She has improved since I saw her at St: Petersburg— The house was crowded— The air of Vive Henry quatre was performed, and applauded a little— There were allusions in the Tragedy, which might have been noticed but were not— The Play finished soon after ten.

20. VI:15. My Servant Michel Antoine Justa, a Piemontese having asked my permission to be absent a month, to go and see his relations, I advised him to quit my service, with a promise that if he returns in a Month and I have further occasion for his service I will take him again— He left me this day, and began his journey. I paid morning visits to Messrs. Crawford and Clay, and to Messrs. Erving, Russell and Storrow— Mr Crawford was at home, and still unwell— I found also Mr Erving at his lodgings, but neither of the other Gentlemen. I called on Mrs Smith at the Hotel de l’Europe, to enquire if she would go and dine with us at the Count de Tracy’s; but her child being unwell she declined— On returning home just at 5 O’Clock I received a note from Count Laval inviting me to dine with him this day; and to an Evening party on Wednesday— I sent immediately an answer, and at six called and took up Mr Smith, and went and dined at the Count de Tracy’s— The family were all assembled— The Count and Countess de Tracy, and their son Victor—General La Fayette—his son George, with his wife a daughter of Mr de Tracy, and their three children— The Count and Countess de Laubepin another daughter of Mr de Tracy, and their two children, a Son and daughter— There were only two Strangers besides ourselves; and one of them was the celebrated traveller Alexander Humboldt— After dinner General La Fayette’s daughter, Madame de la Tour Maubourg came in with her two daughters— The Duke de Noailles, his father in Law, and Mr Dupont de Nemours— It was an agreeable and social party, and I received the thanks of all the family for the good-office I had the opportunity of shewing to Victor de Tracy— I came home between nine and ten.

21. V:30. Employed the morning in writing to my Mother— To send the Letter by Mr Storrow— Just before eleven O’Clock Mr Clay called upon me, with a ticket to be present at the installation of the Court of Cassation, which had been furnished to Mr Crawford, with another for Mr Clay—Mr Crawford continuing unwell and confined to his chamber sent me his own ticket. The hour marked upon it was precisely eleven— We proceeded immediately, but were so late that we found the hall already crowded and could obtain but very indifferent places— There was a Mass performed previously to the installation; in another Hall which was also much crowded, so that those who heard the Mass could not be present at the installation. After the Mass the Procession entered consisting of the Chancellor of France Mr d’Ambray, the new appointed First President of the Court of Cassation, the three Presidents and forty Counsellors or Members of the Court, the Procureur General and his six deputies and the Clerks— The Chancellor d’Ambray read a Speech, stating the motives upon which the king had seen fit, to re-constitute this Court, the Supreme Court of appeal from all the Courts of the kingdom— The principle assumed was that the Court could not be legitimate unless constituted by the king— Some, a small number of the former members have been removed. Their appointments had been for life—but peu importe, for that said the Chancellor, as nothing but the kings appointment could make them irremovable— The Chancellor paid many compliments to the members of the Court who were retained, and most particularly to the new made first President, Mr Deséze— When the Chancellor finished his speech there was a general clapping of hands, of which some of the judges in their scarlet Robes set the example. A plain young man standing next to me, said with some emotion—Il me semble qu’on ne devroit pas applaudir un Chancelier de France— The first President Deseze followed next in another written speech in which he returned with fourfold interest all the Chancellor’s compliments, and spoke with eloquence of St: Louis, Henry quatre and Louis 18— The Procureur General made a very short speech which was not clapped— That of the first President had been applauded though not quite so much as the Chancellor— They all speak thick, and all have harsh and inharmonious voices— After the speeches the Oath was administered to the members of the Court— It was first read by one of the
Clerks, and then the members of the Court were called over by name; each member of the Court rising as his name was called, extending his arm and hand to the elevation of the shoulder, the palm of the hand downwards and saying je le jure—after which the procureur general demanded that the Ordinance constituting the Court and the proceedings of the day should be registered, and the Chancellor declared la séance est levée— My Clay took me home to my lodgings— At half past five I called upon Mr: and Mrs Smith at their lodgings, Rue Taitbout N. 9. to which they moved this Morning, and went with them and dined at Mr Boyd’s. Mr Hubbard, and one other English Gentleman were the only company excepting Mr Boyd’s family. I went home with Mrs: Smith, after which I paid a visit to Messrs: Carette and Minguet and their Ladies, and not finding them at home left Cards, and returned to my lodgings at nine in the Evening.

22. V:15. I was employed all the morning in writing to the Secretary of State, and was preparing about 2 O’Clock to walk out, when a succession of visitors, detained me at home, untill near five— My old Classmate Benjamin Beale was the first— Then the Chevalier Brito, General Robert Fagel and Count de Tracy; with all of whom I had a variety of Conversation— Mr: de Tracy told me that he had sent to Mr Jefferson, a small work upon political economy, which Mr Jefferson had procured to be translated and published in America— That it was written during the time of Buonaparte, when he Tracy, did not care to have it published here, and he was equally averse to publishing it here now— Fagel said much of the state of affairs at Vienna, and appeared under some anxiety with regard to the State of Affairs in his own Country.— Half an hour before dinner I walked out and met in the Palais Royal Mr Erving; who walked with me, and told me of the capture of the Frigate President, of the failure of the Bank-Bill in Congress, and of the British besieging New-Orleans.— I dined at home, and at 9 in the Evening went to Count Laval’s, where there was a small party upon the birth-day of his daughter Zénéide— Shortly after I went in a Gentleman came up and accosted me, articulating several sentences, but of which I could not comprehend a word— I intimated to him that I did not distinctly understand what he said, and he continued speaking two or three minutes in the same manner, and then left me and accosted another gentleman in the same manner— We were much surprized, and some of the company said he must be crazy, until a Gentleman smiling said it was Monsieur Lécomte a Ventriloquist, and slight of hand juggler—he was there for the amusement of the company— He soon after returned to me, and asked me if I had understood what he had said to me before— I said not one word— He said that it was merely a manner of speaking, by which a person standing on one side of him could understand him while a person on the other could not— He was then continually passing round among the company and took away from five gentlemen successively the crosses suspended at their button-holes— The company then passed into the next chamber, and Mr Lecomte entertained us for three hours with slight of hand tricks and ventriloquism— The last was the most curious— He performed a sort of extemporaneous play, personating a man, his wife, a door keeper, a neighbour and an infant with a succession of dialogues in all those voices. He had an assistant, who towards the close of the Evening, affected to quarrel with him; and for some time part of the company were uneasy apprehending an unpleasant Scene; it terminated however by a reconciliation upon which his assistant, composed, sung, and recited couplets in honour of the Emperor Alexander, of the two daughters and Son of Count Laval, and finally of Madame de Laval, whom he concluded by calling La Mère des Graces— The entertainment finished with verses recited by Mr Lecomte himself in honour of the family and of the company, finishing with the declaration et l’enchanteur est enchanté— I came home between one and two in the Morning.

23. VII:30. The Baron Fréteau de Pény to whom Count Marbois had introduced me at his house last week, and who was then one of the Procureurs Généraux at the Court of Assizes, had promised to procure for me a ticket to attend at the Court of Assize at a very interesting trial— Yesterday I received from him a Card, enclosing a ticket for admittance into the interior of the Hall, this day— I went at nine O’Clock this Morning, and at three successive doors was stopp’d by Centinels keeping guard, with orders to let no person in; not even with tickets— After waiting nearly half an hour, I finally obtained admission— The Hall was extremely crowded— It was however nearly 11 O’Clock when the Judges and Jurors came in— The President of the Court Mr Bastard de l’Etang having taken his seat the Court was opened without any formality by a Crier— Twelve jurors, and two supplementary jurors were sworn, in a similar manner to that of the Oath taken by the members of the Court of Cassation— That is, the jurors Oath was first read by the Clerk, and then every Juror as called out by name rose and said Je le jure— The two prisoners had been previously
brought into Court. Their names were Charles Dautun and Girouard. They were charged with the murder of two persons; the Aunt and the brother of Dautun— There was but one jury for the trial of both the prisoners and for both the murders— The act of accusation was read to them, and both answered they were not guilty of the charges— The Procureur General, a Mr Giraudet addressed the Jury and opened the cause to them; repeating with some additional details, and with occasional comments— The President then began the examination or interrogatory of the accused, an incident altogether incompatible with our practice but which forms a very essential part of a french trial. In this case it consumed three hours of time during which the President was scrutinizing every part of the interrogatories to which the accused had been previously subjected, comparing the answers of the two prisoners with the testimony of the witnesses, and calling upon the accused to account for every inconsistency of their own, and for every variance between their answers and the other testimony— Girouard had uniformly denied every thing— Dautun at four several previous interrogatories had told four different stories— At the first he had denied every thing— At the second he had charged Girouard and himself with the murder of the brother— At the third he had charged himself with both the murders, and exculpated Girouard from both— At the fourth he had again denied every thing, but said he had received from Girouard the key of his brother’s chamber— In this he now persisted— The examination being finished several witnesses were successively called in until near six O’Clock, when the Court adjourned to half past nine to morrow Morning. The witnesses in the first instance are kept in a separate chamber so that those examined subsequently first do not hear the testimony of those called in before them— But after being once examined they are suffered thenceforth to remain in Court.— I came home, dined and went to the Odeon Theatre, where I saw Amélie, La bonne Mère, and Une journée à Versailles, performed by the French Company— It was near midnight when I came home.

24. VII:30. Before Nine this Morning I was at the Palais de Justice, and found still greater difficulty in obtaining admission than yesterday— My ticket had not been returned to me, and I took this morning the Card from the Baron Freteau to me in which it had been enclosed— With this I finally got in, but this was also now taken from me and not returned. At half past nine the Court met; and the examination of witnesses was continued untill half past five— The last person examined was Girouard’s wife, at his own demand, with the consent of the Procureur Général— At half past five the Court adjourned to seven— I went home and dined and immediately returned but then found it utterly impossible to obtain access to the Hall— After waiting a full hour at the doors, I gave it up and went to the Theatre of the Odeon— They had finished their first play and just began upon the second; which was La Petite Ville; and that was followed by L’auberge de Calais one of the numerous plays lately written here in ridicule of the English. It was again near Midnight when I came home.

25. VII:45. I learn by the newspaper this Morning that the Court of Assize sat almost the whole Night through upon the trials of Dautun and Girouard; the first of whom was found guilty of both the murders, and the other acquitted of both by the Jury— Sentence of Death was immediately pronounced upon Dautun by the Court, and Girouard was immediately liberated— The President pronounced the judgment at three O’Clock this Morning.— I missed after all the most important part of the trial—the defence—the argument of the Council for the prisoners, and that of the procureur général; and the judgment delivered by the President. In the examination of the witnesses, I observed many differences from the practices to which we are accustomed. There was no cross-examination— No objections to any questions, by the Council for the prisoners— In fact they never appeared or spoke during the whole of the trial so far as I heard it.— This laborious dissipation, disqualifies me for all serious occupation at home— My journal has again run several days in arrear, and I neglect the writing of many letters which ought to be written. After writing about an hour this morning, I walked out and lost myself in the Streets of the City two or three hours— Returned just in time to dine at half past four, and then went to the Theatre des Varietés— I saw Patron Jean, le Ci-devant Jeune-homme; Les Anglaises pour rire, and les Habitans des Landes— I had been led to expect much humour and wit in the two last pieces, but they appeared to me flat and insipid— The Parisians are delighted with a coarse and vulgar caricature of English women; but there is nothing ingenious in it— Le ci-devant jeune homme, of which I had heard nothing amused me more than all the rest— A rake of 60, with his doctor and his Mistresses, his drugs, and his debauches, affecting the licentiousness of youth, and tortured with gouts and rhumatisms, was inimitably performed by Potier, one of the principal actors at this Theatre— They begin at 6. an hour sooner than the others; but finished this Evening not before eleven.

26. VII:30. Mr Storrow called upon me this morning, and mentioned that he should leave the City to-morrow evening, or Tuesday Morning to go and embark at Havre for America— I have only two or three Letters in preparation for him; and shall probably not find time for writing others. I received a Letter from my wife dated 31. January— She then expected to leave St: Petersburg on the 5th: of February— She must in that case have passed Königsberg before this— I sent to my Landlady Madame Coran to enquire if we could have apartments to accommodate us in this house—by the 15th: of this Month— She thinks not; but supposes we may at her mother’s— I walked out and called upon Mr Crawford whom I found yet quite unwell—confined to his chamber, with symptoms at-present of the Jaundice. I afterwards called on Mr and Mrs Smith at their lodgings. On returning home I found Mr Todd at my lodgings.— He said that Mr Bayard and Mr Russell did not incline to be presented to the Duke and Duchess of Orleans— That Mr Clay and himself did— And that he had found the person to whom it was necessary to write to ask for a presentation— It was Count Thibaut de Montmorency, the premier Gentilhomme de la Chambre of the Duke— As Mr Brito had promised me to go with me I told Mr Todd I should not write, and that if Mr Clay and he wrote, we could meet there. In the Evening I went to the French Theatre and saw Tom Jones à Londres, a Comedy in five Acts in verse, by Desforges; and the Malade Imaginaire of Molière. In the procession after the second play, almost all the Actors and Actresses of the Theatre successively presented themselves. I sat next to a Frenchman whom I found very ready to converse; and with whom I conversed more than was perhaps necessary— The spectacle finished but little before midnight.

27. VII:45. I wrote this morning a short Letter to my father, and prepared my packets to send by Mr Storrow— Just after twelve O’Clock at Noon, the Chevalier de Brito, came and I went with him to the Palais Royal; where I was presented to the Duke of Orleans— He asked me whether I was the son of Mr Adams who had been President of the United States when he was in America, and on my answering in the affirmative, he said he saw the resemblance between me and my father; but did not recollect having seen me in America— I told him that I was at that time in Europe. He said he had a very grateful remembrance of the hospitality with which he had been treated in America, and was very happy to make my acquaintance— The presentation was over in less than a quarter of an hour, and I returned to my lodgings, where Mr Storrow immediately afterwards called to take my letters and dispatches for America— He said he should leave the City about the middle of the day to-morrow, and asked me for letters of Introduction to any of my friends at Washington. I promised to bring or send them to him before he should go— I then went and left Cards at the Hotel of the Duke de Plaisance, for his Son, the Duke Charles and his Lady, Count Marbois’s daughter; and also at the Hotel de Bourbon for Mr Gibbs. At a quarter before three I went to the Palais des Arts, where I met the Chevalier de Brito, and attended at a meeting of the first Class of the National Institute— General Andreossi read the conclusion of a Memoir upon the aqueducts of Constantinople, which he had commenced last week— Several Reports were read, and among the rest one upon a new printing-press invented by Lord Stanhope— Part of a Memoir by a physician of St: Domingo upon the geological composition of the West-India Islands was read; but it was so tedious that it soon drove away part of the company, and shed poppies upon those that remained. I was not a little amused at observing numbers of the grave academicians slumbering in their chairs, while it was with extreme difficulty that I preserved myself from the infection. After the Memoir had wearied out two successive readers, the President observed that the Class had heard enough to form a sound estimate of its merit, and appointed a Committee to report upon it— There were about 30 members of the Class present at the meeting; they came and went away as they pleased, and were often engaged in separate conversations two or three together, requiring the use of the President’s Bell to restore silence— The only person among them whom I knew was Mr Humboldt, a foreign Member. About half past four the President declared the Seance levée— I came home, and soon after went and took up Mr Smith with whom I went and dined at Mr Hubbard’s— The company at dinner was about thirty, and as many more came in the Evening— I sat next to Mrs Hottinguer at table, and in the Evening played whist with Mr Hottinguer, and two other Gentlemen, strangers to me. It was near Midnight when I came home. Mr Hubbard lives in a splendid Style.

28. VII:30. Mr Brito had advised me to write to the Countess de Vérac, Lady of Honour to the Duchess of Orleans, the request to be presented to the Duchess— I wrote accordingly this Morning, and received this Evening the answer—that the presentation would be at half past eight o’clock to-morrow Evening— Mr Erving called and sat with me nearly two hours in Conversation upon various topics, political and personal— I wrote two Letters of introduction, to Mr Monroe, and Mr Hellen, and took them to the Hotel de l’Empire, to Mr Storrow, who was prepared to leave the City this afternoon— I also found Mr Bayard and Mr Todd at their lodgings. Mr
Russell shortly afterwards came in to Mr Bayard’s and was going out with him— Milligan was with Todd— Mr Bayard told me he had seen Lord Castlereagh this Morning— He arrived the Night before last and lodges at the Hotel de l’Empire— He says Lord Castlereagh has no disposition for a commercial Treaty, and that he gave him very substantial reasons against it— Todd informed me that Mr Clay and he had not been presented yesterday to the Duke of Orleans— I told him that they might still be presented both to the Duke and Duchess to-morrow evening; by writing to the Count de Montmorency and the Countess de Verac.— I walked on the Boulevard’s to the Porte St. Denis, down that Street to the Pont au Change, over the Pont Neuf and on the Quays to the Museum where I spent an hour— Returned home, and after dinner went to the Opera Comique— Saw the first Representation of Felicie, ou la jeune fille Romanesque; with Rose et Colas— The new Opera was successful, and the names of the authors were demanded— They were announced to be Mr Emmanuel Dupety and the Music by Mr Catrufo— The whole is barely tolerable.

Day. The spirit of dissipation I must suppose inseparable from a visit to Paris— I now scarcely ever rise before seven— Often but a few minutes before eight— I can do little and seldom any thing more than the reading of the morning before breakfast, which is at nine. From that time until two in the afternoon, I appropriate to writing, when not otherwise engaged— But I have several times been called abroad immediately after breakfast, and for the rest of the day; and at other times visits to be paid or received have occupied all the morning. Between two and five, I walk for exercise, and for curiosity and amusement— I dined at five, when at my own lodgings— The usual dining hour abroad is six. I go to some one of the theatres after dining at home, and return from them between eleven and twelve at Night— When I dine abroad, I usually come home between nine and ten— Paris to me is and will be a mere pastime.
